conclusion: Determine the ratio v1/v2 such that the total travel time from point A to point B is minimized.
Total travel time is the sum of time spent running on the beach and swimming in the sea.
Distance from A to the point where the path intersects the coastline is d1 and from there to B is d2.
Angle of incidence is θ1 and angle of reflection is θ2.
Time taken to run on the beach is t_run = d1/v1.
Time taken to swim in the sea is t_swim = d2/v2.
Total time T is T = t_run + t_swim = d1/v1 + d2/v2.
Use principle of time minimization in optics, equivalent to path satisfying Snell's law.
Path length in the sea can be expressed using trigonometry.
Horizontal distance from A to the point where the path intersects the coastline is x, vertical distance is h.
Distance d1 is d1 = x tan θ1.
Distance d2 is d2 = sqrt((x cot θ2)^2 + h^2).
Use law of sines in triangle formed by points A, intersection point, and B.
Time is minimized when path satisfies condition sin θ1/v1 = sin θ2/v2.
θ1 + θ2 = 90° by properties of angles of incidence and reflection.
Substitute sin θ2 = cos θ1 into equation to get sin θ1/v1 = cos θ1/v2.
v2/v1 = cos θ1/sin θ1 = cot θ1.
Ratio of speeds is v1/v2 = 1/cot θ1 = tan θ1.
Need to find specific ratio that minimizes time.
Properties of path that minimizes time give ratio of speeds by ratio of distances in two media.
Ratio of distances determined by geometry of path, given by ratio of sines of angles of incidence and reflection.
